body: Bedlam is served. Dinner in the Guarinos' kitchen at this time of year is accompanied by workers scurrying through with hammers and electrical wire, people screaming such things as ''Where's the hay for the manger,'' Santa adjusting his beard and a rather more somber man popping his head in the back door to say that someone has died again. The
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; THOSE MEGAWATT MIRACLES OF THE CHRISTMAS SEASON

body: NEW construction of manufacturing space is persisting at a modest rate in the city, despite a long-term decline in manufacturing employment. Most of it is being done with city or state assistance by companies that use the space themselves, but a trickle has begun to appear on a speculative basis. In the College Point Industrial Park in Queens, Zano
title: PERSPECTIVES: INDUSTRIAL SPACE; CONSTRUCTION PERSISTS AS JOBS SLUMP

body: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code. In addition, it listed 10 that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Brown's Luncheonette, 3 Lenox Ave. (Central Park N.). Globe Food Services, State
title: 14 OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS

body: A 2-year-old girl was struck and killed by a private sanitation truck yesterday as her grandmother was wheeling her across a Brooklyn intersection in her baby carriage. The girl, Christina Carpenter of 3851 Flatlands Avenue in Brooklyn, was killed at Hendrickson Street and Flatlands Avenue, the police said. The truck driver was not charged.
title: TRUCK KILLS BROOKLYN GIRL, 2

body: Summer school for students who have failed courses in 9th, 10th or 11th grades will be available in New York City public schools this summer for the first time in 11 years. Since 1974, the summer instruction has been available to 12th graders only. The city allocated an additional $1 million this year to the Board of Education for the additional
title: NEW SUMMER SCHOOL COURSES

body: Four years ago Sidney Steinberg and Anthony Clemenza were renovating vacant loft buildings as apartments on lower Broadway in Manhattan. They did 32 units in Nos. 710, 722 and 620 Broadway, selling finished, full-floor apartments. ''But that business is dead,'' Mr. Steinberg said. ''You can't get vacant buildings and the city wants you to pay $5 to
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; CONDOMINIUMS RISE IN FLATLANDS AREA

body: Subject: One-on-one game. Participants: Chris Mullin, ''gym rat,'' versus George Karl, coach. Prize: An official N.B.A. basketball. The basketball matchup took place last Monday at the Coliseum in Richfield, Ohio, between Mullin, the former St. John's University all-American, and Karl, the youngest coach in the National Basketball Association.
title: CHRIS MULLIN SCORES WITH CAVS' COACH

body: Heavy rains, in some places laced with hail, lashed the metropolitan area yesterday, knocking out power to thousands of homes and flooding roadways during the evening rush hour. But the rains seemed to bypass the city's upstate reservoirs. They stood at 60.7 percent of capacity yesterday morning and were not expected to rise much as a result of the
title: RAINS POUND NEW YORK AREA

body: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 100 food establishments cited for violating the health code. In addition, it listed two allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, five closed for having failed to do so and one, previously cited but not closed, that corrected violations. The establishments are these:
title: 100 FOOD OUTLETS LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS

body: SALT LAKE CITY It's known as basketball, but it's really rimball. That's what the players shoot at - a rim, not a basket. Chris Mullin learned to shoot by aiming at the rim on the garage in the driveway of his Brooklyn home. And when the family went camping, the father, Rod, would nail a rim to a tree wherever they were. Soon there were all those
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; THE MULLINS LIVE A FAMILY FANTASY

body: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was in critical condition at Coney Island Hospital yesterday after a van she was riding in plunged into the Mill Basin in the Flatlands section Monday night, killing her four teen-age companions. The girl, Diedra Silverman of 2527 East 63d Street, was submerged in 38-degree water for more than 30 minutes after the van,
title: GIRL IS REVIVED AFTER VAN SINKS IN FRIGID WATERS

body: A group of motorists helped the police corner a robber who shot a man in a holdup at 9 A.M. yesterday in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, according to the police. Four witnesses driving by the shooting chased the suspect in their vans until a police radio car caught up with him, Sgt. John Muldoon of the 63d Precinct detective unit said. ''At one
title: THE CITY; Drivers Help Seize Shooting Suspect
